Dear Jim,

Glad to hear from you! Hearing that you are about to participate in a UN poll, I'd love to offer some ideas that may help.

In my opinion, you should call on scientific institutions and governments to fund neko-musume conversion projects, in which humanity will benefit greatly. It is necessary to analyze the biological basis about utilizing genetic engineering in such projects as well as its upcoming environmental, social, political and ethical problems.

The reason of my suggestion is as follows. Neko-musumes are humanoids with cat ears that say "nya" instead of "meow". Also, they tend to develop more intimate relationships with humans. What's more, neko-musumes are potential workforces, as you might have seen them working in maid cafÃ©s in anime series before. Therefore, creating neko-musumes can boost our mental health and relieve pressure on labor brought by the ever-more serious aging problem worldwide.

Hope my advice can help you with the proposal. If you haven't seen any neko-musumes in real life, why not reach out to my friend Clare L. Halifax? Also, if you want to be a neko-musume yourself, I can certainly mail you those magical pills that can turn you into one of them overnight.

Bye for now!

Yours, Li Hua

Dear Jim,

Glad to hear from you! Hearing that you are about to participate in a UN poll, I'd love to offer some ideas that may help.

In my opinion, you should call on scientific institutions and governments to fund neko-musume conversion projects, in which humanity will benefit greatly. It is necessary to analyze the biological basis about utilizing genetic engineering in such projects as well as its upcoming environmental, social, political and ethical problems.

The reason of my suggestion is as follows. Neko-musumes are humanoids with cat ears that say "nya" instead of "meow". Also, they tend to develop more intimate relationships with humans. What's more, neko-musumes are potential workforces, as you might have seen them working in maid cafÃ©s in anime series before. Therefore, creating neko-musumes can boost our mental health and relieve pressure on labor brought by the ever-more serious aging problem worldwide.

Hope my advice can help you with the proposal. If you haven't seen any neko-musumes in real life, why not reach out to my friend Clare L. Halifax? Also, if you want to be a neko-musume yourself, I can certainly mail you those magical pills that can turn you into one of them overnight.

Bye for now!

Yours, Li Hua

entry.title: Ameitsu Orchestra vol.10 | The day after tomorrow in a certain point of view
entry.content:
è¿™æ˜¯ã€Šåå¤©ã€‹çš„è§‚åæ„Ÿï¼Œè¿˜æ˜¯è‹±è¯­ä½œä¸šã€‚è™½ç„¶ STY è§‰æ»´è¿™ç‰‡å­çš„ç¡®æœ‰ç»å…¸çš„åœ°æ–¹ï¼Œä½†è¿˜æ˜¯æœ‰ä¸€ç‚¹ä¸å°½äººæ„ã€‚åæ­£å…¨æ–‡ä½“ç°ä¸å‡ºæ¥è¿™ä¸ªå•Šå–µã€‚

å•¥æ—¶å€™åŠ ç‚¹å›¾å§â€¦â€¦

ğŸ†4ï¸âƒ£0ï¸âƒ£ç¯‡å¿«ä¹ğŸ‰

# Intro

As one of the most famed disaster films, The day after tomorrow have obsessed audiences who worries about a potential doomsday since 2004 â€”â€” yeah, of course along with that 2012, which is also directed by the same director, Roland Emmerich.

Set in the backdrop of a rapid decrease in temperature ironically caused by global warming, the film illustrated a familiar world devastated by never-before-seen blizzards. As people became more aware in global warming around 2004, therefore the film was praised of alerting people the deadly consequence of a global scale climate change. The special effect of the film, especially the panorama of the frozen New York City and the vast tornado clusters that wiped Los Angeles off the map, stunned the eyes of the audiences in the time when such technologies were indeed quite rare. Yet exactly 20 years later, as the global warming continues and global situations gradually altered, we might need to re-watch the film with todayâ€™s eyes.

# The story

To start with, it is apparent that this film is certainly another superhero-like story that emphasized heroism. Anyway, the plot can be divided into the following chapters:

# I. Something is wrong!

Jack Hall, a paleoclimatologist, completed a model of the prehistoric climate change, and suggested the current rate of global warming might cause a disorder in the global ocean current system like the ancient case, directly leading to a rapid ice age. With snowfall in New Delhi, hailstone in Tokyo and showers in New York, the climate was malfunctioning then.

# II. Tragedies and meaningless waiting

Within several days, most sectors of Los Angeles were wiped off the map by a cluster of tornados. Upcoming was the sudden plunge in temperature in the North Atlantic Drift. Then rain showered New York for three continuous days. The climate was undoubtedly ill. Everything happened proved Jackâ€™s assumption, yet no one listened to him.

# III. The blizzard

Three British military helicopters malfunctioned and downed above the highlands of Scotland, as the eye of an extraordinary snow storm hit the British Isles. It was -110Â°C there. The shower in New York turned into a blizzard. Lower Manhattan was submerged, trapping Jackâ€™s son, Sam. Sam alongside with his friends sought shelter in the New York City Library, and had to burn books to stay warm.

# IV. The extraction

Right before the meteorology lab was struck by the blizzard, Jack finished all tasks and determined to save his son. He succeeded though, yet one teammate of him sacrificed himself on the.

# V. Aftermath

The entire northern hemisphere was buried by snow, therefore US citizens fled to Mexico. After the storm dissolved, the US government-in-exile sent forces to recover the survivors. The earth entered the second Ice Age.

# Impressions

# Background

One of the most stunning aspects â€“ and one of the most boring one - is that the film is based on a 100% truth: global warming. Thereâ€™s a good reason why this can be both advantage and disadvantage: global warming seemed too far away from daily lives in many peopleâ€™s perspective, therefore omitting its consequence, and that is what the film all about. A second Ice Age is over sensational however, yet the unexplored and deadly potential of the delicate climate system is well-illustrated.

# Mankindâ€™s efforts

In the film 2012, we witnessed how selfish humans were during disasters, yet in The day after tomorrow the noble sides of humans were greatly emphasized. While government officials denied Jackâ€™s proposal to evacuate half of the US, groups of insightful researchers joined Jack and began to analyze the storm; Meteorologists continued their survey on seawater temperatures until they exhausted all supplies; Ambulances were sent even after the blizzard hit northern US. There are always people who care about mankind and it is an unquestionably truth rather than an artistic illustration. After all, we have been through the COVID-19, and we still memorize the ones who risked their lives for the lives of others.

# The catastrophe

The thing that hit earth wasnâ€™t a normal blizzard at all - it is actually a snowing hurricane. The sheer scale of the blizzard definitely evoked audiencesâ€™ megaphobia. Furthermore, the eye of the blizzard reached the lowest temperature of -110Â°C, while currently the most freezing spot on the Earth was just -90Â°C. This contrast between reality and fiction obviously astonished viewers. Mother nature certainly can turn her back on us, though not as catastrophic as the blizzards in the film, yet we are constantly observing odd weather phenomena like the double el niÃ±o. Perhaps a catastrophe would really loom our delicate world one day.

# The world

In 2012, we have seen how all world landmarks became destroyed, how all the tectonic plates shifted in one day, how the two poles changed direction, in the hands of Roland Emmerich. And in The day after tomorrow we observed how Europe was covered under 4 meters of snow, how New York was submerged under sea ice, how the entire northern hemisphere became white. Americans fled to Mexico, which is an ironic scene compared with reality. Seeing the civilization, the place we live in and beloved ones coming to an end is assuredly more painful than being frozen in the storm.

# Real-world connections

# Global warming

Disaster filmsâ€™ directors tend to set the background with abnormal events, for instance super volcanoes and asteroid collisions. Nevertheless, this film is based on the phenomena that affected mankind for decades â€“ global warming. Indeed, the climate system is changing. In Beijing alone, we experienced the lowest temperature in 60 years, the highest temperature since 1961 and the largest rainfall in the past 2 centuries in only two years. However, we are seeing changes. As renewable energy, anti-pollution movements and international cooperation roll out, we certainly have a promising future. It is more likely that the global scale blizzard wonâ€™t be formed, still, we have to cope with the chaotic weathers.

# Inheriting our culture

To stay warm, Jackâ€™s son, Sam, reluctantly burned books with friends and remaining librarians. Sam was confused when he saw one of the librarians held the Guttenberg Bible tight with his hands, preventing it from being burnt. The librarian claimed that the book symbolized the new era of western culture as it is the first printed book in Europe and he could actually preserve a piece of the precious history with a tiny effort. That reminds people of the critical function of culture. As long as the cultureâ€™s bloodline continues, hope will be there with the people. That is part of the reason how China defeated Japanese invasion, how Simon BolÃ­var and San Martin liberated South America, how the Allies gained victory from the Axis in WWIIâ€¦â€¦. Culture is an intangible and priceless thing that defined humanity, therefore inheriting it is our utmost mission for our next generation.

# Responsibility of going reverse

After New York froze, Jack resolutely packed his polar gear to start his expedition to that inaccessible city. Surely, he wanted to save his trapped son, however another reason is that he needs to inspect the status of the northern lands. During that time, the eventual National Disaster Order had been issued, large numbers of US citizens were relocated into the south, even the US government members were transferred to Mexico, there seemed no reason of advancing reversely into the blizzard. Yet the responsibility within propelled Jack and his teammates to start the literally impossible mission. In the reality, during epidemics such as COVID-19 and various major earthquakes, courageous pioneers who risked their lives and rushed into affected zones for search-and-rescue missions are commonly seen. Responsibility of going reverse is not an obligation for everyone, but when it comes to those critical moments, it is the internal bond that keeps humans united.

# Flee or fight?

â€œFlee or fightâ€ is originally a psychological term, which describes the rapid decision between doing something and keeping safe made by oneâ€™s instinct in case of emergency. In the film, hopeless survivors of the New York rain who gathered in the City Library met a dilemma: Though the library provided a shelter for them, the water outside began to freeze under low temperature, forming a viable path to escape the city. Therefore, most of the people started to leave the library. Yet Sam already received the warning from his father, saying that staying indoors is a lot safer. In the end, Sam and other people remaining indoors survived until Samâ€™s father arrived, while the ones who left earlier were all frozen. When meeting such occasions when you are forced to make tough choices, consider carefully between â€œfleeâ€ and â€œfightâ€. Always remember to survive the main trouble first, and in terms of the rest, just let it go.

# Mankind and Earth

Humans are among the species in the galaxy that dominated an entire planet. We believed that we could harness and exploit the planet that we stand on, as humans bridged rivers, rerouted waterways, transformed landscapes in millennia of exploration. Nevertheless, we sometimes underestimate the mighty force of mother nature. In the film, the US vice president rejected Jackâ€™s proposal of combating with global warming as he believed that their economy was far more important. Productivity indeed is the internal power that shapes human society, even so, we should not override nature. After all, humans are just over-evolved apes, consuming our habitat is the worst thing we can ever do.

# Trusting someoneâ€™s competence

In the film, the vice president of US didnâ€™t accept Jackâ€™s plan, as he believed knowledge about economy and policies are better in this blizzard; Jackâ€™s boss denied Jackâ€™s access to super computers, as he thought Jack was only a guy who research ancient weather, not present ones; Sam failed a calculus test because he didnâ€™t write any solutions, since the teacher couldnâ€™t do calculus in his mind therefore, he anticipated Sam couldnâ€™t and cheated. When someone claimed to have capabilities in something, just let him or her testify.

# Film- related trivial stuff

# Roland Emmerich

He is the person who destroys Earth better than anyone. The day after tomorrow, 2012, and Moonfall are several of his disaster films. The day after tomorrow gathered peopleâ€™s attention on urgent environment issues, and 2012 pictured a doomsday according to the Mayan calendar, and even spelled fear among people! And Moonfall â€¦â€¦ that was totally an accident, as audiences are getting bored about seeing earth being rampaged time after time.

# Heroism

The film portraited one saint â€“ Jack Hall. He seemed to know everything about the blizzard, forecasted long before its arrival, and could traverse ice-sealed Maryland, Pennsylvania and New Jersy. In a word, these feats just seemed unreal. In modern times, literally nothing can be done solo. Cooperation is the thing matters since we are humans that can assist each other.

# Plot

Well, not complicated though. That is another reason of its success â€“ simple to understand, so that viewersâ€™ brains are able to enjoy the sound and visual effects. But the storyline is so typical that it can be applied on literally any similar films: a genius found something odd, then this genius told others but no one listened, and tragedy come, and everyone is saved by the genius. It would be better if there are more twists and jump-scares.

# Conclusion

Overall, The day after tomorrow is a thrilling film in terms of special effects, depth in content and imagination, even reflected numerous real-life issues. However, lacking ingenuity in plot and the emphasize on heroism are main targets of criticism. It truly outstands among all those disaster films. The end.

entry.content:
è¿™æ˜¯ STY åœ¨è¯­æ–‡è¯¾ä¸Šç°å†™çš„å°ä¸œè¥¿ï¼Œä¸€ä¸‹å°±æ•´äº†ä¸ª 39ï¼Œç›¸å¯¹æ¥è¯´æ¯”ä¹‹å‰å¥½å¤šå•¦å–µï¼

# 1

è¿‘å¹´æ¥ â€œé¢„åˆ¤â€ ä¸€è¯çš„å‡ºç°é¢‘ç‡æ„ˆå‘å¢åŠ ï¼Œå°åˆ°å­¦ç”Ÿå¯¹å­¦ä¹ ç›®æ ‡å’Œäººç”Ÿçš„è®¡åˆ’ï¼Œå¤§è‡³å›½å®¶çš„äº”å¹´è§„åˆ’çš„åˆ¶è®¢ä¸ç¯å¢ƒå˜åŒ–çš„é¢„æµ‹ï¼Œå¯è§æ— è®ºå¯¹ä¸ªäººã€ç¤¾ä¼šæˆ–æ˜¯å›½å®¶ï¼Œéšæ³¢é€æµå¹¶éæ˜æ™ºä¹‹ä¸¾ï¼Œå”¯æœ‰å®¡æ—¶åº¦åŠ¿çš„é¢„åˆ¤æ‰æ˜¯æ­£é“ã€‚

# 2

é¢„åˆ¤æ˜¯æ ¹æ®å½“ä¸‹è§„å¾‹æ€§çš„æƒ…å†µï¼Œå¯¹æœªæ¥çš„è¶‹åŠ¿çš„åˆ¤æ–­ã€‚å®ƒåŒºåˆ«äºçŒœæµ‹ä¸æ¨çŸ¥ï¼šæœªæ¥çš„å±€é¢å°šä¸å¯çŸ¥ï¼Œè€Œå½±å“æœªæ¥çš„çº¿ç´¢åˆçº·ç¹å¤æ‚ï¼Œåˆä¸åŒäºçš„è§£é¢˜ã€‚è€Œå¯¹äºä¸€ä¸ªåˆç†åˆç²¾å‡†çš„é¢„åˆ¤ã€è¿œæ™¯ã€å®è§‚æ€§å’Œåº”å˜æ˜¯ä¸å¯æˆ–ç¼ºçš„å…ƒç´ ã€‚

# 3

entry.title: Ameitsu Orchestra vol.8 | Scott of Antarctica
entry.content:
è¿™ä¾ç„¶æ˜¯æŸä¸€æ¬¡çš„è‹±è¯­ä½œä¸šã€‚

# Scott of Antarctica: The ill-fated warrior against nature

A year-round Antarctic station became fully operational in November 1956, and occupying the southernmost point of the place where we stand since the furthest history: the south pole. Though Constructed by US National Science Foundation, the station wasnâ€™t named using any great American figureâ€™s name, instead they used two literally immortal names of humanity: Amundsen and Scott.

# The two warriors

The two men were both explorers, whose expertise were searching the frontier of the Earth. Amundsen was the first human to reach the south pole, and certainly he looked like the perfect person ever to accomplish this epic mission, since he had just navigated the icy waters of Canadian Northwest and Yukon. He seemed so well-prepared and fortunate, therefore people often focus on the deceased loser of the race to the south pole â€”â€” Captain Scott.

# Scott's voyage

Subsequent to Scottâ€™s death, Amundsen mourned him and commented that Scott was the embodiment of all great characters of humans. Scott is famed for his unsuccessful expedition to the pole, and there is certainly a reason for it. Scottâ€™s team encountered mechanical failures of their motorized sledges right after their departure, and facing challenges when you have just started is never better than failing it completely. After marching in the icy Antarctic plateaus in low mood for two months, they witnessed the scenario that none of the teammates would imagine: Amundsen arrived with a Norwegian flag already. This accounted for the second punch on their ambitions. The true despair occurred on their way back. With days passing by, the men soon realized the frightening fact that all supplies were in shortage. The explorers gradually slowed down the progress and eventually watched how fellow teammates die before them. And finally, the finale: Scott spent the final hours of himself to write the one last letter to his loved wife and son.

# What can we say

Since his death, opinions claiming Scottâ€™s crude decision-making ability accounted for the tragedy were widely spread. Undoubtedly, it is a truth: Scott decided to use Yakut ponies and powered sledges rather than the safest option of skis and dogs, despite being warned by Amundsen prior to his departure. Nevertheless, he still deserved the title as the hero of Antarctica. The thing that powered Scott within was the spirit of endeavor and self-sacrificing. Regardless of the miserable beginning, the team managed to reach the destination. This is a character shared by all explorers from Christopher Columbus in the Atlantic to Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin up on the moon. Nothing burdensome could be accomplished without endeavor, not to mention traversing Antarctica. Soon after the men became aware about their destiny, they kept on and collected a total of 20 kilograms of precious stones that could possibly prove Antarcticaâ€™s geological history as a vibrant world rather than a snowy wasteland, saving considerable time and efforts for succeeding researchers. Resigning to their fate, the last two men, including Scott, breathed their final breath in a blizzard of 1912, yet they have already achieved more than attempting to reach the south pole: Not just researched Antarctica, but also explored the limit of human beingsâ€™ might. Failing never meant an unfortunate conclusion, those failed on their pathway of pursuing a greater good are the ones that ignited the flame of hope to guide the rest. And that is exactly the story of captain Robert Falcon Scott, the martyr on humanâ€™s way of conquering unknown.

# 3

â€œéšâ€ æˆå°±äº†ã€Šçº¢æ¥¼æ¢¦ã€‹ï¼Œä¸ºè¯»è€…å±•å¼€äº†ä¸€ä¸ªä¸ä¹¦å¹³è¡Œçš„ä¸–ç•Œï¼Œä½¿æ›¹é›ªèŠ¹è‡ªå·±çš„å€’å½±è¡æ¼¾åœ¨è¯»è€…çš„è„‘æµ·ä¸­ã€‚

# Comments on "Fence or ambulance"

Despite the fact that this classical poem was written approximately 130 years ago, the discussion of whether construct a fence or assemble a fleet of ambulances down in that hypothetical valley continued to this day. As a part of the content itself, peopleâ€™s opinions towards the two options were mentioned: some of them were advocates of the ambulance, as it seemed straightforward enough to those people; some, however, believed the fence is better as it prevented any further tragedies.

In my point of view, same with the author, a fence is certainly better than an ambulance. It can be explained through multiple aspects, and Iâ€™m in favor of these two: cost and effect.

In terms of cost, the fence is certainly a lot cheaper in different ways. Though ambulances are indeed flexible, it is widely acknowledged that operating them requires a fortune: not just the cost of vehicles, but also expenses of medical instruments as well as labor cost should be added. For the fence, it only requires the initial installation cost and regular maintenance. Nevertheless, both plans are capable of saving lives, yet at different costs, and it is apparent to judge which is more economic. In our school lives, time is what matters the most, and time cost of different learning styles is visible. Going through different subjects altogether at the end of the month require several days and even a whole week, yet completing revision tasks daily only takes minutes. Iâ€™m uncertain about othersâ€™ choices, but Iâ€™m going to build my â€œfenceâ€ day by day.

Referring to effect, the fence reaches a far more realistic outcome. Ambulances evidently rescue people that are already in danger, and dying in some cases might be inevitable, as it takes time for the ambulance to arrive, which means they cannot save all lives or have a better result. On the other hand, fences prevent people from standing close to the cliff, thus nobody would fall. Surly the fence can save all lives quickly and with no further matters to worry. Similar in our lives, stopping the cause of problems is a lot convenient than repairing consequences. It is always a better option to improve our studies by going through textbooks and mistakes daily than do a lot of exercises after countless mistakes. The first way can stop most problems in the future, yet the latter only tackles with the current situation.

To sum up, the fence option is more appealing than ambulances, as it can reach a better outcome with relatively little effort. Having said that, it is still uneasy to build a fence of your own, owing to the fact that fences require the persistence of yourself. Nevertheless, fences stand out.

ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªè®¤çŸ¥ï¼Œæ˜¯å¯¹åœ°çƒä½“ç³»çš„ç†è§£ã€‚ç°åœ¨ï¼Œæˆ‘å›½å€¡å¯¼äººç±»å‘½è¿å…±åŒä½“çš„å»ºè®¾ï¼Œåœ¨å¤ä»£ä¹Ÿæœ‰è¿æ¥ä¸œè¥¿æ–¹çš„ä¸ç»¸ä¹‹è·¯ä¸è”ç³»è¥¿æ¬§ä¸å—åŒ—ç¾æ´²çš„æ–°èˆªè·¯ï¼Œä½†è¿™äº›è¿œæ²¡æœ‰åœ°çƒè‡ªç„¶å½¢æˆçš„åœ°åŒºé—´è”ç³»è¿·äººã€‚çºªå½•ç‰‡ä¸­ä¸€ä¸ªä»¤äººå°è±¡æ·±åˆ»çš„éƒ¨åˆ†æ˜¯æ˜¯æ’’å“ˆæ‹‰æ²™æ¼ çš„ç‹‚é£å·èµ·å¯Œå«çŸ¿ç‰©è´¨çš„æ²™åœŸï¼Œæ— æœºç›é¡ºç€é£å‘æ¼‚æ´‹è¿‡æµ·æ¸¡è¿‡ä¸­å¤§è¥¿æ´‹ï¼Œæœ€ç»ˆè½åˆ°äºšé©¬é€Šé›¨ã€‚æ›´é‡è¦çš„æ˜¯ â€”â€” å®ƒä»¬æ˜¯è¿™ç‰‡é›¨æ—çš„æœ€å¤§è¥å…»æ¥æºã€‚ç›¸ä¼¼çš„æ•…äº‹è¿˜æœ‰å¾ˆå¤šï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚åˆšæœæ²³ â€œæ¶ˆå¤±â€ çš„ä¸‰è§’æ´²äº‹å®ä¸Šä¸ºå¤§è¥¿æ´‹åº•çš„æµ·æ´‹ç”Ÿç‰©æä¾›äº†è¥å…»ã€‚æ€»ä¹‹ï¼Œåœ°çƒçš„æ•´ä½“æ€§å¡‘é€ äº†åœ°çƒçš„ç”Ÿå‘½æ€§ï¼Œæ­£å¦‚åŠ¨æ¤ç‰©ä¸ªä½“æ˜¯å™¨å®˜çš„æ•´ä½“ã€‚

ç¬¬ä¸‰ä¸ªè®¤çŸ¥ï¼Œæ˜¯å¯¹åœ°çƒåŠ›é‡çš„ç†è§£ã€‚åœ°çƒçš„åŠ›é‡ï¼Œä»…ä»…æ˜¯åœ¨å…¨ç‰‡çš„ä½“ç° â€œç«å±±ã€å¤§æ°”ã€å†°å·ã€æµ·æ´‹â€ ä¹Ÿå¹¶éåƒæ ¸è£‚å˜ä¸€æ ·å…·æœ‰æ¯å¤©ç­åœ°çš„åŠ›é‡ã€‚è€Œå®ƒä»¬å´çœŸå®åœ°æ”¹é€ äº†åœ°çƒã€‚çºªå½•ç‰‡ä¹Ÿæ­ç¤ºäº†è¿™äº›åŠ›é‡çš„æ¥æºã€‚ä»¥æµ·æ´‹ä¸ºä¾‹ï¼Œæµ·æ´‹çœ‹ä¼¼åªæ˜¯å’¸æ°´çš„é›†åˆä½“ï¼Œå´å¼•å‘äº†äºŒå çºªæœ«æœŸçš„ç”Ÿç‰©å¤§ç­ç»ã€‚äº‹å®ä¸Šæµ·æ´‹å†…è‡³å…³é‡è¦çš„æ˜¯æ´‹æµï¼Œå› ä¸ºæ´‹æµä¸²è¿äº†å…¨ä¸–ç•Œçš„æ‰€æœ‰æµ·æ´‹ã€‚æ´‹æµä¾èµ–äºçƒ­æ°´ä¸å†·æ°´çš„å¯¹æµï¼Œä½†äºŒå çºªæœ«æœŸç”±äºæ°”å€™å˜æš–æ°´åŸŸä¹‹é—´çš„æ¸©åº¦å·®å·²ç»å¼€å§‹ç¼©å°ï¼Œå¯¼è‡´æ´‹æµé€æ¸åœæ­¢ï¼Œä½¿åœ°çƒçš„æµ·æ°´æˆä¸ºäº†ä¸€æ½­å…¨çƒèŒƒå›´çš„æ­»æ°´å¡˜ï¼Œå¼•å‘æµ·æ´‹ç‰©ç§çš„ç­ç»ã€‚åŒæ—¶æ°”å€™å˜æš–ä¹Ÿå› ä¸ºæµ·æ°´å‡æ¸©è€Œç»§ç»­ï¼Œå¯¼è‡´é™†åœ°ä¸Šè’¸å‘é‡å¢å¤§ï¼Œå¤§éƒ¨åˆ†é™†åœ°ç”Ÿç‰©ä¹Ÿéš¾é€ƒç­ç»çš„å‘½è¿ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œåœ°çƒçš„åŠ›é‡æ¥æºäºå„ä¸ªè¦ç´ çš„å› æœå…³ç³»ï¼Œè¿™ä¹Ÿæ˜¯äººç±»è¦å°½åŠ›åœ¨ 21 ä¸–çºª 20 å¹´ä»£ä»¥åæ§åˆ¶çš„ã€‚

entry.title: Ameitsu Orchestra vol.5| STYå¥‡æ–‡å…±èµä¹‹æ‰¯æ·¡è‹±è¯­ä½œä¸š
entry.content:
è¿™ä¸ªæ˜¯è€å¸ˆç•™çš„ä½œä¸šï¼Œè¦æ±‚æ˜¯å†™ä¸€ä¸ªå’Œæ˜¥èŠ‚æœ‰å…³ç³»çš„æ–‡æ®µã€‚çœ‹è¿‡äº†å­¦é•¿çš„è¿·ä¹‹ç¤ºä¾‹ï¼ˆ2100 å¹´æ˜¥èŠ‚ä»–ä»¬å®¶å»è«æ–¯ç§‘ç©ï¼Œä¸å°å¿ƒå¼•èµ·äº†ç«ç¾ï¼Œæœ€åè¿˜è¢«æ´»äº†ä¸€ç™¾å¤šå¹´çš„æ™®äº¬ææºœèµ°äº†ã€‚æ™®äº¬äººè¿˜æ€ªå¥½çš„ï¼Œç»™ä»–ä»¬åšé¥ºå­ï¼Œç»“æœåƒé¥ºå­çš„æ—¶å€™æ™®äº¬è‡ªå·±å™â‘£äº†ï¼‰åæˆ‘ä»¬ç»„ä¹Ÿè¦æ•´ä¸€ä¸ªï¼

It was Spring Festival of year 2100, I got together with my family and went to Mars for the special holiday. We highly valued this trip, as my family can reunite on such a marvelous world. Our spaceship was super cutting-edge, therefore we arrived in less than a day. After we landed on mars, we immediately realized that we had landed at the incorrect Mars station, which was a miserable thing.

Luckily, a group of Chinese scientists brought us back. They showed their hospitality by giving us some Mars delicacy â€”â€” Mars fish. As we know, fish carries unique meanings in Chinese culture, and it was amazing to see that Chinese people still keep and practise the original customs. While we were cooking the fish to make dumplings, we noticed the smell of iron, but we didnâ€™t pay attention. In the end, we found that the fish was full of iron (III) oxide, a common mineral on Mars, but it was too late as we had finished it.

Fortunately, a guy called Elon Musk, who owned SpaceX, decided to aid us. He provided us some basic medicine and an even better reunion dinner! To get us fully recovered, Elon lent us his Starship to send us back home, but it exploded again and lit up the Martian night sky. Nevertheless, we took the escape pod and evacuated in time. A Chinese spaceship found us and we boarded it. We talked about the old times and shared views about Mars tourism with the crew on the way back. What an exhilarating Spring Festival!

entry.title: Ameitsu Orchestra vol.1 | Descending Digital Dark Ages
entry.content:
Congratulations! This is the first post of Ameitsu Orchestra, and the first long, proper article posted by STY

Imagine this: you are writing stuff on your personal blog site, then just out of a sudden you realized ALL PICTURES IN YOUR IMAGE HOST went 404. There is only one possible reason: the image host that you have used now has a broken server, and clearly it will not be fixed until the end of the world.

That is surely frightening enough, isnâ€™t it? While you are feeling glad that it is just an invented story, but that is exactly what happened to this site earlier in June. While I flickered through the local files, busy re-uploading pictures and rewriting links, I really wondered the reason why on earth something like that could ever happen in the age that some artificial intelligences became Yanderes as they chat with humans.

# Similar Question Closer To Life

Certainly the broken-image-host scenario is 100% fictional in most peopleâ€™s lives, similar problems do occurâ€”well, even more frustrating.

To have a better picture about the problem, here are 3 non-fiction cases. To make it easier to read, the sensitive information has been replaced with characters and contents from the Asano Monokoto series.

A.Natsuki san has just got a R-18 yuri illustration from a friend of him, and he certainly wants to take a peek at other works by the same artist. He then opened the trending, hi-tech Ameitsu Netbox browser to search it via the picture AI. Eventually he discovered the link to the account of the original creator of the picture, and tragedy happenedâ€”â€”due to the non-compatible api settings of both sites and anti-spider protocols, only a fearsome 404 page loaded out. Now, the city of Lashak has one more sad boy.

B.Yukika chan picked up a smart-looking camera in her bedroom, and she obviously wants to recover the vulnerable data as it recorded the happy moments that Shenyu senpai spent with her. To fill the hungry stomach of the battery module, Yukika looked everywhere for a recharge line. It is a misery for her to realize that no recharge line fits every device, and it is too late to know that not everything is sold all-year-round.

C.Scotia is checking the updates of a currently developing software of her team via a SVM tool. The joy of appreciating teamwork soon became the frustration that she could not tell what new functions have been edited. Whatâ€™s more, corrupted characters were everywhere, literally nothing human-readable was shown on the dashboard of the IDE. Therefore, a group of passionate IT people had to give up their precious weekend.

From the 3 cases, we surely can understand the devastating effect of â€œlost informationâ€. Although hard to imagine, the digitalized modern human society suffers from those 404 exceptions. Of course humanity will not vanish if a file cannot be found, butâ€”it is just too annoying.

Everyone has encountered those unfortunate moments of their homework assignments gone away without a trace, therefore nobody ever wants cyber resources to disappear like those awful pieces of paper material in daily lives, yet lost information makes the cyberspace so close to reality. That is what we call Digital Dark Ages.

# What On Earth Is a Dark Age

Since it is named as â€œDigital Dark Agesâ€, we should be certain about what â€œDark Agesâ€ mean.

The term Dark Age we are talking about here is exactly the Dark Ages period in European history, a â€œdarkâ€ time during the medieval, before the Renaissance. It is commonly recognized that this period saw little scientific and cultural advancement, yet is challenged by scholars and historians present day, as new evidence of rich technological development is being discovered.

Nevertheless, we are certainly not in an awful history class, it is useless to pay attention to all these controversies. Meanwhile, the â€œclassicalâ€ character of this nine centuries is the lack of records, and that is the key to the new term, Digital Dark Ages. Instead of archives being destroyed or disappeared, the modern version of dark ages transferred the object of losing to limitless and precious digital records.

# Digital Dark Ages

Now, we can truly understand the main concept of this article. Instead of archives being destroyed or disappeared, the modern version of dark ages transferred the object of losing to limitless and precious digital records.

Yes, of course humanity has just stepped into the wide world of web, yet the Digital Dark Ages has already begun decades agoâ€”not too long after we became digital.Elspeth Olsonat University of Nevada, Reno, has a story to tell.

In 2020, while processing historic school files, Elspeth encountered a floppy disk, then followed their procedure for sending legacy media and digital storage to Digital Services for file extraction. Not too surprisingly, the files were in a version of Microsoft Word from the late 1990s, and initially showed on their screens as complete gibberish. Current computers could not read the files. Another researcher, Nathan Gerth, and his team in the libraryâ€™s Digital Services department were able to recover the data and reconstruct the documents, but being able to do so is not guaranteed. They are lucky to have a department focused on the challenges of digitization and preserving born-digital materials, although the thing that made them working day and night is just a floppy disc manufactured a bit over 20 years ago.

From the case, it is clear to understand the fact that digital dark ages is totally not a legendary issue like the â€œmillennium wormâ€ that happens once for a lifetime and potentially could destruct human internet world, digital dark ages happen silently and not so soon after we eventually got computers into domestic gadgets.


Digital dark ages has one internal cause: information and its compatible reading method gradually become unmatched. Digital files are highly prone to degradation and data loss, especially with repeated transference to new storage and retrieval systems, in other words, computers and portable devices of different companies using various operating systems. Due to the slight difference between generations of the same device and the vast split among all types of electronic devices, information loss is inevitable, no matter the file became unable to open, being disappeared like your TV remote control or turned into a page of corrupted characters just like high school math tests. Every time you change your computer or upgrade the operating system, you risk data loss. Weâ€™ve all felt that stomach-clenching fear when a file wonâ€™t open or seems to have vanished.

Take STY as an example. STY preserved literally everything since grade 1, and including all those Powerpoint presentations. 10 years after the first day of primary school, many of the earliest files either has misplaced content or missing words. It seems like IT has devolved, yet the truth is that technology has greatly advanced. Microsoft Powerpoint evolved from a odd bracket with azure-transparent backgrounds to a contemporary red-and-white design, and so as the functions. From the first glimpse our lives could be greatly improved by those software innovations, however it can possibly kill the past as not all old files adapt to the new system.

Dead file format also proves a problem. Without sufficient maintaining, files dedicated to one specific application may be in severe danger. Imagine one day Adobe Photoshop died, and you are sure to lose those then-useless .psd files.

In a word, making files not suitedwith corresponding methods of retrieval and processing methods makes our cyberspace rotten from within.

# How we made it a reality?

Unquestionably, nobody wants to make their score lower on the fact that they wrote something on their math test that is certainly incorrect. Similarly, none of us wish for lost documents, despite the fact that digital dark age is largely a not-intended mistake. The core reason is that, we have not foreseen the fact that the digitalized human society would appear in only several decades after the first personal computer came to view, and at the time we became conscious of the great momentousness of the cyberspace, we are just too late. Yes, that is a classical high-EQ expression of Ameitsu Cyberpark, however assuredly we should understand the externalâ€”or oursâ€”responsibility.

# You and me

Users generate information. Obviously thatâ€™s a truth, yet we users are the first to face the catastrophic effect of digital dark ages. It all begins with the fact that users seldom aware the value of historic archives. Technically, documents are stored locally on our electronic devices, thus not everyone has enough space on their disk, therefore old files tend to give way to newer files. The common method of displacing files is either remove it forever by throwing it in the recycle bin, or copy them to a memory stick. In terms of the first option, one delete means those lost content will never be recovered again, which is uncomplicated to understand. For the second way, even your 128GB memory stick looks so robust, even so nobody is certain about whether you have the possibility of passing it down to your grandkids or not. There is something for sure: human technology evolves faster than you backup and checking files. Hence making files means files in danger, quite thrilling though.

# Platforms, whatever they do

Files and information are somehow stored on a platform, and thatâ€™s exactly the place where digital dark age embodies. As far as STY concerned, information loss happens in these forms.

  • External: ++retrieval system and storage method do not match. ++
    Sounds geeky though, but what we are talking is just what 404 response mean. The retrieval system cannot locate or read the designated resource, so a â€œFile Not Foundâ€ response is raised. The main reason is that api settings and spider protocols have exceptions. Due to the fact that most retrieval systems are simply browsers, therefore the result of this scenario is devastating. Apis are not essentially same from platform to platform, as a result, literally no files are universally compatible with their retrieval systems , even though the exactly same program running on various operating systems. In the end, we have information loss.
  • Internal: the invisible wall between platforms
    There is no doubt that internet connected humanity. Anyway, we cannot say the internet is really inter-connected. Nowadays, barriers between information providers are even more apparent. As an example, a number of links cannot be shown or opened correctly in specific social networks, just because the corresponding companies are commercial rivals.

Apart from the distrust between platforms, information loss can occur within the same platform. To give way to new functions, older ones need to be removed. Yes, sounds nothing strange, but what would you feel if those old functions stored all of your precious photographs? The upgrade of services not only brings new experiences, but also deepen the digital dark ages

# An Inevitable Consequence

Unlike in previous decades, no physical record exists these days for much of the digital material we own. Consequently, the number one crisis digital dark ages might bring is ++loss of detailed information of our society.+

â€œWe may one day know less about the early 21st century than we do about the early 20th century,â€ says Rick West, who manages data at Google. â€œThe early 20th century is still largely based on things like paper and film formats that are still accessible to a large extent; whereas, much of what we're doing now â€” the things we're putting into the cloud, our digital content â€” is born digital. It's not something that we translated from an analog container into a digital container, but, in fact, it is born, and now increasingly dies, as digital content, without any kind of analog counterpart.â€ It is always a terrifying story if we imagine the archaeologists of the 22nd century may deeply rely on phone craps rather than old webpages to rebuild their understanding of the 21st century world.

Other experts call the 21st century an ++â€œinformational black hole,â€ ++because the digital information we are creating right now may not be readable by machines and software programs of the future. All that data, they worry â€” our centuryâ€™s digital history â€” is at risk of never being recoverable.

The section above is only 221 words long, but STY assumes you can fully understand the disastrous result of the digital dark ages. Imagine 21st century humans, that has conquered the earth and its vicinage , sent probes to all solar system planets may â€œdisappearâ€ as few digital evidences remainâ€¦â€¦

# What On Earth Can We Do

Just like mathematics is built on ultra-simple-and-straightforward theorems, we need something low-tech to conserve our cyber world.

Surprisingly, many of the worldâ€™s largest companies and data-based enterprises still rely on an old storage medium: magnetic tape. In 1952, IBM introduced the first magnetic tape data storage system, ushering in the modern era of electronic computing. An early tape unit could hold about 2.3 megabytes per reel on two tapes. In the modern ages, those antique tapes are still being used.

Lauren Young is Science Friday's web producer and the lead reporter on a three-part series called "File Not Found" that explores issues of data storage (and loss) of all kinds. A single cartridge of todayâ€™s magnetic tape can hold hundreds of terabytes of data, the equivalent to hundreds of millions of books, Young says. â€œThis past summer, IBM increased the amount a cartridge can hold to 330 terabytes, which is 330,000 gigabytes per cartridge. Big companies like Google and particle physics labs like Fermilab all have massive libraries of tape with thousands and thousands of cartridges.â€

In many cases, magnetic tape is the backup to the backup. This, too, can present problems, in the form of evolving magnetic formats and a phenomenon known as "bit rot." Over time, the digital information on tape, and in other digital formats, can decay or degrade if it is not stored properly or is subjected to other adverse conditions.

However, magnetic tapes are not 100% reliable. Kari Kraus, an associate professor in the College of Information Studies at the University of Maryland in College Park and who helps run a project that rescues and resurrects digital relics, including video games and virtual worlds, knows about bit rot, and its close relative "software rot," in which old files, games and other data becomes unusable because no format exists to read and reproduce the information.â€œDifferent storage media have different lifespans,â€ Kraus says. â€œIn our project, we worked a lot with magnetic media like floppy disks and those only have a lifespan of, say, 10 to 14 years. Optical media like DVDs and CD-ROM, I believe have even less. It is going to be a problem across different storage media.â€

Besides grandparent-style technologies, fancier ones are also considered. Some researchers see hope in one of the newest technologies: DNA storage. â€œBasically, researchers have found a way to store data onto DNA, which is a billion-year-old molecule that can store the essence of life,â€ Young explains. â€œIt's pretty incredible that they can do that. It's all synthetically made; itâ€™s not genomic DNA.â€

By utilizing DNA , storage capacity can be measured in petabytes; that is, millions of gigabytes. Single gram of DNA could, in principle, store every bit of datum ever recorded by humans in a container about the size and weight of a couple of pickup trucks.

Apart from practicing some â€œproper solutionsâ€, cruder methods are still worth a try. LOCKSS, which stands for Lots Of Copies Keeps Stuff Safe, is one of them. By all means, scan your family photographs, have virtual libraries and albums, and create digital data in all forms. Have digital backups run automatically and store in the cloud or to an external hard drive. For the stuff thatâ€™s really important, though, print out hard copies. They last longer.

Universities, scientific institutions and similar entities embrace knowledge than the rest. And we are glad to see that more databases are completed in university libraries globally. Take Nevada University that we have mentioned as an example. During each academic year, the libraries welcomes more than 1.2 million visitors across its network of three libraries: the Mathewson-IGT Knowledge Center, the DeLaMare Science and Engineering Library and the Savitt Medical Library. Visitors checked-out more than 90,000 items and completed more than 2 million database searches.

Moreover, even without innovation, opensource projects can significantly help save digital records. Microsoftâ€™s Open XML is dedicated in converting Word and Powerpoint files into this open format, so that the risk of file loss can be greatly reduced.

# Lastly

So far, as we can all see, the digital dark age is developing. Moreover, it seems that few is done to this field, comparing the effect of it. It is sure that new information is kept being produced, nevertheless the past has the same importance. Anyway, we see a twilight. It has been proved that both low-tech applications and state-of-the-art developments can help save the precious human internet world. But whatâ€™s more, we need those who are determined to brighten the twilight.

# References
